body: I'm able to reproduce it on Windows (Python 3.8). Will be looking into it.

Since [_TbatsAdapter](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/sktime/forecasting/base/adapters/_tbats.py) has old interface. At the same time will refactor to respect current @kejsitake [template](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/f68f92e927a05e2e09cd03e01c9dcd78563ea9b2/extension_templates/forecasting.py#L222)

issue.title: [ENH] Prediction intervals refactor: BATS/TBATS; bugfix for #1625; base class updates on `predict_quantiles`

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
 Fixes #1625 


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Fixed #1625. 
Implemented TBATS `_predict_quantiles()`.

##### Re-implemented `_has_predict_quantiles_been_refactored()` due to failing tests.

[Previous implementation](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/bce815d11fff62b52882f13cd650c88972b08ab6/sktime/forecasting/base/_base.py#L1250):  
```python
def _has_predict_quantiles_been_refactored(self):
    if "_predict_quantiles" in type(self).__dict__.keys():
        return True
    else:
        return False
```
Relied on the expectation that `type(self)` (last class in inheritance chain) would be class implementing `_predict_quantiles()`, and thus `type(self).__dict__.keys()` would have `"_predict_quantiles"`. 

BUT in case of TBATS `type(self)` is [TBATS class](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/bce815d11fff62b52882f13cd650c88972b08ab6/sktime/forecasting/tbats.py#L21) which does not re-implement itself but rather inherits implementation from [_TbatsAdapter](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/bce815d11fff62b52882f13cd650c88972b08ab6/sktime/forecasting/base/adapters/_tbats.py#L18). Thus `type(self).__dict__.keys()` does **not** have `"_predict_quantiles"`, and returns _undesired_ `False`.

Suggested implementation:
```python
def _has_predict_quantiles_been_refactored(self):
    """Check if specific forecaster implements _predict_quantiles()."""
    base_pq = BaseForecaster._predict_quantiles
    this_pq = self.__class__._predict_quantiles
    # true if self's _predict_quantiles is new implementation
    return base_pq != this_pq

```
Relies on following expectations: `BaseForecaster._predict_quantiles` [is defined ](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/bce815d11fff62b52882f13cd650c88972b08ab6/sktime/forecasting/base/_base.py#L1164)(which it is), `self.__class__._predict_quantiles` or equivalently `type(self)._predict_quantiles` always exist (since `BaseForecaster` is expected to be in the inheritance chain). If any class in the inheritance chain from `BaseForecaster` to `type(self)`/(`self.__class__`) has re-implemented `_predict_quantiles` then `base_pq != this_pq` would be _desired_ `True`.

##### Small changes to  `predict()`.

[In previous implementation of `predict()`](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/bce815d11fff62b52882f13cd650c88972b08ab6/sktime/forecasting/base/_base.py#L239). This line has expectation of `alpha` to be iterable/ list. While alpha can be scalar/float.

```python
coverage = [1 - a for a in alpha]
```
Suggestion:
```python
alphas = [alpha] if isinstance(alpha, (float, int)) else alpha
coverage = [1 - a for a in alphas]
```
ensures that float/int becomes a list with that float/int.

Also `else` [clause ](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/bce815d11fff62b52882f13cd650c88972b08ab6/sktime/forecasting/base/_base.py#L236)was missing definition for `y_pred` that is expected in return:

Added
```python
y_pred = self._predict(self.fh, X=X_inner)
```

##### Small changes to `_convert_new_to_old_pred_int()` due to failing tests.
This one needs a bit of story :)

[test_predict_pred_interval](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/bce815d11fff62b52882f13cd650c88972b08ab6/sktime/forecasting/tests/test_all_forecasters.py#L258) failed thus:

[this line](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/bce815d11fff62b52882f13cd650c88972b08ab6/sktime/forecasting/tests/test_all_forecasters.py#L282)
```python
y_pred, pred_ints = f.predict(return_pred_int=True, alpha=alpha)
```
where `alpha=0.05`

in [`predict()`](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/bce815d11fff62b52882f13cd650c88972b08ab6/sktime/forecasting/base/_base.py#L240)
```python
pred_int = self.predict_interval(fh=fh, X=X_inner, coverage=coverage)
```
where `coverage=[0.95]`

`predict_interval()` calls [`_predict_interval()`](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/bce815d11fff62b52882f13cd650c88972b08ab6/sktime/forecasting/base/_base.py#L1157) 

which has these lines

```python
alphas = []
for c in coverage:
    alphas.extend([(1 - c) / 2, 0.5 + (c / 2)])
alphas.sort()
```
after these lines `alphas = [0.025000000000000022, 0.975]`, which become columns for the multiindex returned by [`_predict_quantiles()`](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/bce815d11fff62b52882f13cd650c88972b08ab6/sktime/forecasting/base/_base.py#L1161)

**Notice first quantile `0.025000000000000022`!** since `(1 - 0.95) = 0.050000000000000044` not so fun numerical instability :(.

once returned back to `predict()` we are executing [these lines ](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/bce815d11fff62b52882f13cd650c88972b08ab6/sktime/forecasting/base/_base.py#L243) to convert from new to old:
```python
if keep_old_return_type:
    pred_int = _convert_new_to_old_pred_int(pred_int, alpha)
```

Now actual **problem**:

[Previous implementation of _convert_new_to_old_pred_int](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/bce815d11fff62b52882f13cd650c88972b08ab6/sktime/forecasting/base/_base.py#L1308):


```python
def _convert_new_to_old_pred_int(pred_int_new, alpha):
    name = pred_int_new.columns.get_level_values(0).unique()[0]
    alpha = check_alpha(alpha)
    pred_int_old_format = [
        pd.DataFrame(
            {
                "lower": pred_int_new[name, a / 2],
                "upper": pred_int_new[name, 1 - (a / 2)],
            }
        )
        for a in alpha
    ]

    # for a single alpha, return single pd.DataFrame
    if len(alpha) == 1:
        return pred_int_old_format[0]

    # otherwise return list of pd.DataFrames
    return pred_int_old_format
```

takes original `alpha=0.05` and attempts to construct expected column index name `[name, a/2]` here again `alpha` is expected to be a iterable/list but is float (so fixed).

BUT the main problem is **`a/2=0.25` exactly `0.025` and thus fails to get actual column `0.025000000000000022`**

Suggested implementation, simply replicates the computation path to arrive to exactly the same values of quantiles.

```python
def _convert_new_to_old_pred_int(pred_int_new, alpha):
    name = pred_int_new.columns.get_level_values(0).unique()[0]
    alpha = check_alpha(alpha)

    alphas = [alpha] if isinstance(alpha, (float, int)) else alpha
    coverage = [1 - a for a in alphas]

    alpha_quantiles = []
    for c in coverage:
        aq_pair = ((1 - c) / 2, 0.5 + (c / 2))
        alpha_quantiles.append(aq_pair)
    alpha_quantiles.sort()

    pred_int_old_format = [
        pd.DataFrame(
            {
                "lower": pred_int_new[(name, al)],
                "upper": pred_int_new[(name, au)],
            }
        )
        for al, au in alpha_quantiles
    ]

    # for a single alpha, return single pd.DataFrame
    if len(alphas) == 1:
        return pred_int_old_format[0]

    # otherwise return list of pd.DataFrames
    return pred_int_old_format
```

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
No

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?
- general code comments (my first commit :))

#### PR checklist

TODO
##### For all contributions
- [ ] Will add myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).

issue.title: [BUG] Error when predicting from (T)BATS when the forecasting horizon is longer than the time series used in training

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
In sktime 0.9.0 there is an error, when `predict` function is called on a fitted (T)BATS model in case when forecast horizon is longer than the time series used for training. This is purely sktime-related, since the forecasts from `_forecaster` are still possible.

**To Reproduce**
```python
from sktime.forecasting.tbats import TBATS
from sktime.forecasting.bats import BATS
from statsmodels.tsa.arima_process import arma_generate_sample

# dummy time series for predictions - length 50
y = pd.Series(arma_generate_sample([2], [2], (50, 1)).flatten())
tbats_model = TBATS()  # the same for BATS
tbats_model.fit(y=y)

tbats_model.predict(np.arange(1, 10))  #OK
tbats_model.predict(np.arange(1, 25))  #OK
tbats_model.predict(np.arange(1, 50))  #OK
tbats_model.predict(np.arange(1, 51))  #OK
tbats_model.predict(np.arange(1, 52))  #ERROR (forecast horizon of 51 steps)
tbats_model._forecaster.forecast(52) #OK
```

**Expected behavior**
Well, no error I guess.

**Additional context**
Error message:
```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
~\AppData\Local\Temp\4/ipykernel_24092/2542756290.py in <module>
----> 1 tbats_model.predict(np.arange(1, 52))

c:\<hidden>\.venv\lib\site-packages\sktime\forecasting\base\_base.py in predict(self, fh, X, return_pred_int, alpha, keep_old_return_type)
    195         # this is how it is supposed to be after the refactor is complete and effective
    196         if not return_pred_int:
--> 197             y_pred = self._predict(
    198                 self.fh,
    199                 X=X_inner,

c:\<hidden>\.venv\lib\site-packages\sktime\forecasting\base\adapters\_tbats.py in _predict(self, fh, X, return_pred_int, alpha)
    125             lower = pd.Series(out["lower_bound"])
    126             upper = pd.Series(out["upper_bound"])
--> 127             pred_int = self._get_pred_int(lower=lower, upper=upper)
    128 
    129         else:

c:\<hidden>\.venv\lib\site-packages\sktime\forecasting\base\adapters\_tbats.py in _get_pred_int(self, lower, upper)
    186             pred_int["idx"].isin(fh_out.to_indexer(self.cutoff).values)
    187         ]
--> 188         pred_int.index = fh_out.to_absolute(self.cutoff)
    189         pred_int = pred_int.drop(columns=["idx"])
    190         return pred_int

c:\<hidden>\.venv\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\generic.py in __setattr__(self, name, value)
   5476         try:
   5477             object.__getattribute__(self, name)
-> 5478             return object.__setattr__(self, name, value)
   5479         except AttributeError:
   5480             pass

pandas\_libs\properties.pyx in pandas._libs.properties.AxisProperty.__set__()

c:\<hidden>\.venv\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\generic.py in _set_axis(self, axis, labels)
    668     def _set_axis(self, axis: int, labels: Index) -> None:
    669         labels = ensure_index(labels)
--> 670         self._mgr.set_axis(axis, labels)
    671         self._clear_item_cache()
    672 

c:\<hidden>\.venv\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\internals\managers.py in set_axis(self, axis, new_labels)
    218 
    219         if new_len != old_len:
--> 220             raise ValueError(
    221                 f"Length mismatch: Expected axis has {old_len} elements, new "
    222                 f"values have {new_len} elements"

ValueError: Length mismatch: Expected axis has 1 elements, new values have 51 elements
```

**Versions**
<details>

System:
    python: 3.9.5 (tags/v3.9.5:0a7dcbd, May  3 2021, 17:27:52) [MSC v.1928 64 bit (AMD64)]
executable: c:\<hidden>\.venv\scripts\python.exe
   machine: Windows-10-10.0.18363-SP0

Python dependencies:
          pip: 21.3.1
   setuptools: 56.0.0
      sklearn: 0.24.2
       sktime: 0.9.0
  statsmodels: 0.12.1
        numpy: 1.19.3
        scipy: 1.7.3
       Cython: 0.29.25
       pandas: 1.2.5
   matplotlib: 3.5.1
       joblib: 1.0.1
        numba: 0.54.1
     pmdarima: 1.8.2
      tsfresh: None
</details>
